answers.author: Chase Carlile
answers.text:
Boston, MA put together a task force to review their PILOT program in 2009, and they released their report in April 2010.  I was unable to find any of their agreements, but on the task force's website you can their final report, as well as reports from some of the organizations, including colleges, that participate explaining how the organization supports the community.  The website is: 
http://www.cityofboston.gov/assessing/PILOT.asp
I hope this helps.

answers.author: Peter Dunn
answers.text:
Hi Eric, 
One of the nominees for last year's ICMA's Community Partnership Award was a Missouri city that successfully negotiated a PILOT agreement with a local college. The agreement was based in part on the college's public service improvements. I'd encourage you to check out their award nomination document at the link below, and to try to contact the city of Clayton for more information. 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/302406/Nomination_for_Community_Partnership_Award

author: Eric Norenberg
text:
The City of Oberlin is home to many churches, schools, and local, state and federal facilities that results in approximately half the property in the community being exempt from property taxes.  Our largest tax-exempt property owner is a private college.  Our City Council is interested in negotiating a Payment in Lieu of Taxes (PILOT) agreement with the college to support general fund operations (police, fire, streets, code enforcement, etc.).
Could anyone share examples of PILOT agreements that have been agreed to in your communities please?  (Agreements with colleges or universities would be most helpful, but examples of PILOTS with other non-profits would be helpful as well.)  In addition, if there are any studies or other research that can be shared regarding the benefits vs. impacts of colleges/universities that might have bearing on this subject, we would appreciate those as well.
Thanks!
Eric
title: Payment in Lieu of Taxes (PILOT)
